div.head: Answer of Thomas Edwards.
div.p: The Severall Answer of Thomas Edwards Esquire one of the Defendants to the Bill of Complaint of Forest Edmund Eshfeild Esquire Complainant

All advantages of excepcion to the incertaintys insufficiencys & other imperfecions & by the Complainants Bill of Complaint conteines to this Defendant now and of all times hereafter so said for answer thereunto or unto soe much thereof as any way concerns this Defendant as he is advised to make
answer unto he this Defendant answereth and saith That he hath heard that Rice Davis Esquire in the Plaintiffs Bill named was seized in Fee simple or of some other Estate of Instance in the Mannors & Lands in the Plaintiffs bill mencioned But what were or are the yearly values thereof this Defendant knows not neither doth this Defendant
know or ever heard of any conveyances Settlements or assurances the said Rice Davies made thereof or of any part thereof nor has seen any deed or writing purporting any such settlement And this Defendant hath heard that the said Rice Davies had issue by Mary his wife one only Daughter to witt Elianor the
Plaintiffs Grandmother who intermarried with Nicholas Pointz Esquire in the Plaintiffs Bill named and severall other Daughters by former wives But this Defendant knows not neither ever heard of any Contract or Articles made on the marriage of the said Elianor with the said Nicholas Pointz to such effect as in the
Plaintiffs Bill is sett forth or so any other effect whatsoever Neither doth this Defendant know of any Fine or Recovery levyed or suffered by the said Nicholas Pointz & Elianor his wife during their Intermarriage of the Mannors & Lands in the Bill or any part thereof of any Deed or deeds by them executed
declaring the uses of any Fines or Common Recovery And this Defendant hath heard the said Nicholas Poyntz dyed without Issue But about what time cannot sett forth But hath heard and beleives the said Elianor his wife survived him And that she afterwards intermarried with William Goodrick Esquire in the said Bill
named the Plaintiffs Grandfather But this Defendant knows not nor ever saw or heard of any Settlement made of the same premisses or any part thereof either before or after their Intermarriage to any uses intents or purposes whatsoever And this Defendant hath heard and beleives it may be true that the
said William Goodrick and Elianor his wife had Issue between them only one child (to witt) Elianor the Plaintiffs mother And that Elianor the Plaintiffs Grandmother dyed many years since but about what time knows not leaving the said Elianor the Plaintiffs mother very Young And that the said William
Goodricke did survive her and held such of the Mannors and Premisses whereof the said Elianor the Grandmother dyed seized during his life and dyed alsoe before the Plaintiffs said Mother attained one and twenty years of Age as he hath heard and this Defendant hath also heard and beleives that the
Plaintiffs Mother after the decease of her Father was during her minority under the care and Intention? of Sir Francis Goodrcik Knight & Sidney Bere Esquire or one of them as her Guardians untill she married or 'till she attained the Age of one and twenty years And this Defendant hath also heard and
beleives the said Elianor the Plaintiffs mother intermarried with Edmund Ashfeild Esquire the Plaintiffs Father but about what time knows not And beleives it may be also true that they had Issue the Plaintiffs their only Son and Mary their only Daughter And this Defendant doe beleive the said Edmund
Ashfeild & Elianor his wife Did in Michalmas Terme in the Twenty ninth year of the reigne of our late Sovereigne Lord King Charles the second levy and acknowledge to Sidney Bere Esquire and Robert Forrest Esquire and their heirs or the heirs of one of them One Fine sur connzance de
droit come ceo & of the Mannors of Tickenham als Ticknam with the appurtenances & of twenty Messuages five Cottages Sixteen barnes two Costs two Watermills One Dovehouse twenty two Gardens one and twenty orchards two hundred and twenty one acres of land two hundred thirty three
acres of meadow two hundred and ten acres of pasture thirty four acres of wood one hundred acres of Furze & heath Five hundred acres of Moore three pounds Eight Shillings rent and Common of pasture for all Cattle with the appurtenances in Tickenham als Wraxall Cleevedon
Nailsey Clapton Portbury Backwell Loxton Stogursey and Shurton and that the uses of such Fine were in and by one Indenture bearing date the Eighteenth day of January in the said Nine and Twentieth year of the Reigne of our late Sovereigne Lord King Charles the second made
between the said Edmond Ashfeild and Elianor his wife of the one part and the said Robert Forrest and Sidney Bere and one Francis Crestwell Plowden Esquire of the other part declared to be such uses intens and purposes as the said Elianor by her last will & Testament in
writing or by any other writing under her hand and seale attested by two or three credible witnesses should limitt direct and appoint for that he finds in his Custody an Abstract of such Fine and deed and beleives the Chirograph of the said Fine and the Deed tending the
uses thereof are now remaining in the custody or power of the Defendant Thomas Merrick and unto which this Defendant does referr himself And this Defendant saith then he neither knows beleives or ever heard of any other Deed or writing whatsoever that was ever made sealed or
executed by the said Edmund Asheild and Elianor his wife or either of them declaring the uses of the said Fine (Except the said Indenture dated the said Eighteenth day of January in the said Nine & twentieth year of the Reigne of his said late Majesty King Charles the second
Neither doth this Defendant know of Any Declaracion or appointment made or executed by the Plaintiffs mother pursuant to that Deed for the Plaintiffs Benefitt or for any other intent or purpose whatsoever save what is herein after sett forth And this Defendant hath also heard and beleives the said
Edmund Ashfeild dyed and that the said Elianor the Plaintiffs mother survived him and afterwards intermarried with Richard Glanville Gentleman But about what time the said Edmund Ashfeild dyed or about what time the said Elianor intermarried with the said Richard Glanville
this Defendant cannot sett forth And this Defendant hath also heard and beleives That upon and before the intermarriage of the said Elianor with the said Richard Glanville She the said Elianor with the consent of the said Richard Glanville Did convey settle and assure All her
Mannors & Lands in the County of Somersett unto and upon Edward Gorges Esquire and William Rogers Esquire and their heirs to the use of them and their heirs In Trust for the seperate use and benefitt and to make such Grants & disposicions thereof as shee aone and seperate
from the said Richard Glanville should from time to time direct and appoint Which Settlements this Defendant hath often seen and beleives are also in the custody or power of the said Defendant Thomas Merrick unto which this Defendant referrs himself And this Defendant beleives the said
Richard Glanville & Elianor cohabited together for some time and had such Children as the Bill mencions But this Defendant hath heard and verily beleives the said Elianor lived very uneasy & uncomfortable with him not only by reason of his extravagency but by reason
of continuall Sollicitacions to settle her Estate on him as she hath often told this Defendant And she often informed this Defendant that her vsage was such that she was oftentimes afraid of her life And therefore had secreted herself and resolved to live private from from him And she
also informed this Defendant that the said Richard Glanville haveing by accident gott her into his power did imprison her in some lodgings for severall days in London till he had prepared such Deeds for her to seale as he thought fitt and haveing compelled her to execute the same
he endeavoured to enter upon and deprive her of All or the greatest part of her Estate Whereupon one or more suites were brought in this court to invalidate and Sett aside the deeds and writings by her executed by such compulsion as aforesaid And upon the hearing thereof
the same Deeds were ordered to be delivered upp and cancelled And this Defendant beleives they were delivered upp and cancelled accordingly And from that time the said Elianor lived Seperate and a part from the said Richard Glanville and held and enjoyed her own Estate
to her own seperate use till her death as this Defendant verily beleives And this Defendant doth confesse that upon occasion of the Suites aforesaid and upon such other occasions as are after mencioned not only the writings before mencioned but severall other deeds and writings relating to the
said Elianors Estate may have been in his custody or power but after the perusall of them and such use made of them as was necessary to prosecute and defend those Suites and other the occasions after mencioned they were either redelivered to the said Elianor or deposited by her
order into the hands of the severall mortgages herein after mencioned and this Defendant doth confesse he received either from the said Edward Gorges or from the said Elianor Glanville but from which of them he cannott sett forth the Deeds of Settlement made by the said Elianor
on her marriage with the said Richard Glanville in order to defend the said Suites or in order to borrow money on her Estate for her use Which Settlements were after by their privity & consent left with the mortgages after named together with all the other deeds
relating to the said Estate which ever came into this Defendants custody And beleives they all now remaine in the custody or power of the Defendant Thomas Merrick Vnlesse Such as are mencioned in the Schedule hereto annexed And himself referrs to such answer as he shall
make thereabouts But this Defendant utterly denys that to his knowledge or remembrance he ever had in his custody or ever saw any deed or writing whatsoever importing a Settlement of the said premisses or any part thereof on the Plaintiffs or whereby he had or could
justly clayme the same or any part thereof save one Indenture of Lease dated the thirteenth day of March one thousand Six hundred Ninety eight whereby the said Elianor for the naturall Love and affecion to the Plaintiff directed the said Trustees to grant and they did accordingly
grant a Tenement to the Plaintiffe in the West Town of Tickenham To hold from the twenty twenty fifth day of the then instant March for three years under the rent of a Pepper Corne Which Lease this Defendant caused to be drawn & ingrossed by her order as & for a maintenance for him She
telling this Defendant She had an inclinacion to try his good Husbandry or to that effect And to this Defendants remembrance She told this Defendant the tenement was worth thirty poundsa year And that She had repaired it for him to dwell there And about Six months after the said Elianor
//IMG_0324, IMG_0327, IMG_0328//lb/> complained to this Defendant That the Plaintiffe had been very idle and extravagant And She heard was selling the Lease for twenty or thirty pounds or some such small summe Whereupon this Defendant advised her to buy it herself or send some person to buy the Lease for her And the said
Elianor came afterwards and told this Defendant that the Plaintiffe had agreed to take twenty pounds for the Lease and desired this Defendant to gett a writing made for assigning that Lease to Richard Butler Esquire In Trust for her with assignments this Defendant prepared and gott ingrossed
accordingly And the Plaintiffe Sealed the said Assignment which is now in this Defendants custody and dated the Eighteenth day of December One thousand Six hundred ninety nine and this Defendant said the Plaintiffe execute it and signs the receipt for the twenty pounds And this
Defendant hath in the schedule hereto annexed sett forth All such writings relating to the Title of the said Elianor Glanvilles Estate as were in his custody at the time of her death which schedule he prays may be taken as parte of his answer and denys that he had any other
writings in his custody at her death save what is herein and in the said Schedule annex'd mencioned And this Defendant saith he beleives it may be true that the Plaintiffs Father and Mother in their Life time Did by Fine and Deeds morgage great part of the said Mannors and premisses
to Sir Thomas Higgons in the Plaintiffs Bill named for securing one thousand pounds and Interest And that the said Sir Thomas Higgons Assigned his mortgage afterwards to Dame Anne Goning widow who afterwards intermarried with Sir Dudley North who lent the said Elianor
Glanville more money And had All the rest of her estate made for its Security And the said Sir Dudly dying and Dame Anne his wife surviving him Did assigne the premisses to Sir William Merrick Knight deceased who from time to time lent Mrs Glanville more moneys and had
Addicionall Securitys made therefore And the said Sir William Merrick also dyed haveing before his death made his will And the Defendant Thomas Merrick Executor thereof who haveing proved the said Will accounted with the said Elianor Glanville in her life time and upon makeing upp
that account to this Defendants best remembrance there was at that time due to him from the said Elianor the summe of two thousand Seaven hundred and fifty pounds for securing whereof she executed some writing declaring the said debt And that the whole mortgaged premisses should stand and be a
security therefore And this Defendant beleives the other Defendant Sir Henry Goodrick since her death made upp another account with the said Defendant Thomas Merrick & borrowed other moneys of him soe that the whole Debt due to the said Thomas Merrick out of the said Estates amounts to the summe
of three thousand Five hundred pounds All which Securitys this Defendant beleives now remain in the custody or power of the Defendant Thomas Merrick And this Defendant humbly referrs himself to such Answer as the said Thomas Merrick shall make thereabout And this Defendant doth confesse that
he hath given out as the truth is that the said Elianor made her will in writing dated on or about the thirtieth day of July 1705 And thereby directed the said Edward Gorges and William Rogers out of the rents and proffitts of the said Mannors and premisses in the first place to
satisfie and pay to the Defendant Thomas Merrick the money due to him upon mortgage And in the next place to pay certain Legacys therein mencioned And as to All her Mannors and Lands in the County of Somersett After her debts maintenance & porcions paid She
devised & bequeathed the same unto the other Defendant Sir Henry Goodrick his heirs and assigns for ever and made him Sole Executor thereof Which Will she read over and duly considered as this Defendant beleives for that she had it in her custody for that purpose and then Sealed and
published it in the presence of this Defendant and Severall other Witnesses and took it away with her and beleives she kept it in her custody till her death And this Defendant saith that at the same time she sealed and executed a Deed poll bearing equall date with her said Will
wherein it is recited that the said Elianor Glanville whilest she was sole by her Indentures Lease and release bearing date the twenty third and Twenty Fourth days of November which was in the first year of the Reigne of the late King James the second Did Grant release &
confirme unto the said Edward Gorges and William Rogers their heirs and assigns All that her Mannors or Lordshippe of tickenham with all & singuler its rights members & appurtenances in the said County of Somerset And also All those her Mannors or Lordshipps of Rodney Stoke and Cheddar with All and
singuler their rights members and appurtenances in the said County of Somersett And all and singuler her Farmes Lands Tenements & hereditaments scituate lying and being within the severall Parishes of Backwell and Loxton or either of them in the said County of Somersett And all
houses outhouses edifices buildings Dovehouses barns stables Courtyards Cartillages Gardens orchards lands meadows pastures feedings Commons proffitts commoditys advantages hereditaments and appurtenances whatsoever to the said Severall Mannors Lordshipps Farmes tenements Lands and
premisses and to every or any of them belonging or apperteining or therewith usually occupied or enjoyed or accepted reputed deemed or taken as part parcell or member thereof And also All other the Mannors Lordshipps Messuages Lands Tenements Farmes and hereditaments whatsoever
scituate lying and being within the County of Somersett aforesaid whereof or wherein she the said Elianor was seized of any Estate of Inheritance and All rents herriotts and Services referred due or payable upon or by any demise Lease or grant demises Leases or grants made or
granted of the said Mannors Lordshipps Messuages tenements Farms Lands hereditaments & premisses and every or any part or parcell thereof And the revercion and revercions remembrance & remberances thereof and All her Estate and Interest therein (to be had and holden to the said Edward Gorges and William Rogers their
heirs and assigns forever to the only proper use and behoof of them the said Edward Gorges and William Rogers and of their heirs and assigns forever more and therein reciting further that in and by one Indenture Tripartite bearing date the Five and twentieth day of November which was in the
said first year of the Reigne of the then late King James the second made Between her the said Elianor Glanville by the name of Elianor Ashfeild of Tickenham in the County of Somersett widdow of the first part the said Richard Glanville by the name of Richard Glanville of the City of
Bristoll Gentleman of the second part and the said Edward Gorges and William Rogers of the third part reciting therein the said last Indentures and that a marraige was agreed upon and shortly to be had and solempized between the said Richard Glanville and her the said Elianor And that it
was declared by & between the said partys to the said last Indenture and every of them especially by the said Richard Glanville testified by his being a party and putting his hand and seal thereto in manner and forme following (that is to say that the said Lease & release before mencioned)
were soe made to the said Edward Gorges and William Rogers and their heirs as aforesaid by and with the privity and consent of him the said Richard Glanville And upon this Trust and confidence in them the said Edward Gorges and William Rogers reposed that they the said Edward Gorges and William Rogers
and the Survivor of them and the heirs of such Survivors should from time to time make such Leases Grants and Estates of All and singuler the before mencioned Mannors Lordshippe Messuages Tenements Farms Lands hereditaments and premisses or any part or parcell thereof
and should permitt and Suffer the rents issues and proffitts thereof to be had released taken and enjoyed by such person and persons as She the said Elianor by any writing or writings deed or deeds under her hand and Seale or by her last Will and Testament in writing
testified by three or more Witnesses Which Writings deeds and will the said Richard Glanville did thereby agree and consent that she might and thereby he did enable her to make the same as if she were a Feme Sole) should from time to time limitt order declare and
appointt And for want of such direcion or appointment that then as the heir of her the said Elianor should direct or appoint She the said Elianor Glanville in and by the said Deed poll In pursuance of the said power and authority to her given and reserved by the
said last recited Indenture Did limitt order declare and appoint That the said Edward Gorges and William Rogers their heirs and assigns should imediately after her decease grant and convey All an singuler the said Mannors Lands Tenements and hereditaments
in the said Indenture or either of them conteined and in such manner as Councill should advise unto the Defendant Henry Goodrick by the name of Henry Goodrick Esquire Son of Sir John Goodricke of Ribston in the County of Yorke Barronett and his heirs and assigns for ever He paying the
Mortgage money due thereon And All other her just debts And the severall Legacys given in and by her will bearing equall date therewith And to which this Defendant John Fleming and Joseph Edwards Gentlemen were witnesses with and under a provisoe that
if she the said Elianor should be minded to revoake or make void the said Deed poll and should by any writing either endorsed thereon or by any other writing under her own hand and sealed and executed by her in the presence of three or more substantiall
Witnesses whereof two or more of such witnesses should be acting Justices of the peace at the time of Sealing thereof that then the said Deed should cease and be void Anything therein conteined to the contrary thereof as anywise notwithstanding Which Deed
poll she left in this Defendants custody where the same remained till her death And is still in this Defendants custody and ready to be produced as this Honourable Court shall direct And this Defendant Saith that soon after the said Elianor had made such Will & appointment
as aforesaid he did acquaint the Plaintiffe with the contents thereof And advised him to be more carefullly submitt to his Mother and be ruled by her and perhapps that might induce her to alter her said Will and Settlement or used words to that effect But could not
observe any inclinacions in the Plaintiffe to take this Defendants advice And the Plaintiffe contrary thereto afterawards prosecuted his Mother in this Honourable Court And endeavoured to sett upp a Title in himself to her Estate And the said Elianor hath often complained to this Defendant that
he had forbad her Tenants to pay her any rent And that he had sold or endeavoured to sell her Hay which Grew upon her Estate and put her at open Defiance And that she had just reason to suspect that he held Correspondence poctbe her be it de with her husband Glanville
and was afraid he would by some meanes or other betray her into the said Glanvilles hands And consulted with the Defendant in what manner she should provide against such an accident fearing if the said Glanville should have her in his power he would transport her
beyond the Seas and compell her to sealle what he thought fitt And this Defendant denyes that he ever observed or heard her complain that the Plaintiffe or his Sister were turned Protestants or expresse any displeasure against them or either of them on that account
But said She hoped as they had changed their religions they would change their manners or to that effect Neither Did this Defendant ever hear her say to his remembrance that they or either of them were not her children but changlings or anything to that
//verso, IMG_0329, IMG_0330//
Effect And this Defendant Saith that he knows not about what time the said Edward Gorges and William Rogers dyed or which of them dyed first But hath been informed that the said William Rogers survived the said Edward Gorges and that
the heir of the said William Rogers hath conveyed the legall Interest of and in the premisses to the said Defendant Sir Henry Goodrick But the name of such heirs or time when the same was done this Defendant knows not he being not concerned in
taking such conveyance And this Defendant Beleives the thousand pounds secured to the said Sir Thomas Higgons was relly borrowed for that this Defendant by order of the Lady Anne Gonning really & bona fide paid him the thousand pounds
with such Interest as was then And therefore at the time he assigned his said Morgage to the said Lady Anne Gonning And this Defendant utterly denyes that he either knows or beleives that the Plaintiffs Mother was at any time during her
life a Lunatick or of an unsound memory or understanding or not capable of managing her Estate or was ever under any melancholy thoughts about her husband Glanvilles absence from her But on the contrary seemed always
Glad that he came not near her And indeed Severall times declared that she dreaded the Sightof him And hoped never to see him again And this Defendant can't sett forth what she made yearly out of her Estate But hath often heard
her say she might make more thereof If the Plaintiffe would not interrupt her And as to the Plaintiffs goeing abroad beyond the Seas this Defendant knows nothing thereof Save that this Defendant hath Severall
times at his return from beyond the Seas by his Mothers order paid him severall summes of money And this Defendant denyes All Combinacion in the Plaintiffs Bill charged or that he knows or beleives that the said Elianor
Glanvilles said Will or appointment herein before sett forth was or were made upon any Trust or for Any other intent or purpose whatsoever Save what is therein mencioned Without that that Any other matter or thing
in the Complainants said Bill of Complaint conteined materiall or effectuall for him this Defendant to make answer unto And not herein & hereby well and sufficently Answered unto confessed or avoided traversed or
denyed is true to this Defendants knowledge or beleife All which matters and things this Defendant is ready and willing to averr maintain and prove as this honourable Court shall direct and humbly prays to be heard
discinsted with his reasonable costs and charges in this behalf most wrongfully susteined.

//4 lines in Latin, September 1710//
Thomas Coules
Joseph Edwards
Hi Neale
